message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pelvic organ prolapse, and the irreducible pink globular mass protruding out of the vagina is consistent with prolapse of the vaginal wall. The loss of urine when coughing, sneezing or exercising suggests stress urinary incontinence. Among the ligaments listed, the uterosacral ligament is the most likely involved in this patient’s condition as it supports the top of the vagina and helps to hold it in place.

We refer to a medical journal article titled "Pelvic Organ Prolapse" for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pelvic organ prolapse, which can be caused by the loss of integrity of the uterosacral ligament. The infundibulopelvic ligament and the round ligament of uterus mainly support the ovaries and the uterus, respectively. The cardinal ligament of the uterus provides support to the cervix and the vagina but is less commonly involved in pelvic organ prolapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with a prolapsed uterus, which can be caused by weakened pelvic support structures. Among the options, the uterosacral ligament provides support to the uterus and cervix, and a loss of integrity in this ligament can lead to prolapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggest a pelvic organ prolapse, specifically a vaginal vault prolapse. The uterosacral ligament supports the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina and a loss of integrity in this ligament can lead to pelvic organ prolapse. The other ligaments listed do not directly support the lower vagina.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irreducible pink globular mass protruding out of the vagina suggests pelvic organ prolapse. The loss of integrity of the uterosacral ligament, which supports the cervix, is most commonly involved in this condition. Infundibulopelvic ligament supports the ovary, cardinal ligament of the uterus supports the cervix and vagina, and round ligament of uterus supports the uterus in the anterior direction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest pelvic organ prolapse. The most commonly affected ligament is the uterosacral ligament, which can cause the uterus and vaginal vault to prolapse. The other ligaments listed are less commonly involved in prolapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the location of the mass suggest a diagnosis of pelvic organ prolapse. The loss of urine when coughing, sneezing, or exercising suggests that the condition involves the urethra. The most likely ligament involved in this patient's condition is the uterosacral ligament, which holds the uterus in place and provides support to the vaginal apex. Damage to this ligament can result in a prolapse of the uterus and/or the vaginal wall, leading to the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The irreducible pink globular mass protruding out of the vagina suggests pelvic organ prolapse. Since the patient experiences urinary incontinence, the loss of integrity of the uterosacral ligament is most likely involved. This ligament plays an important role in supporting the uterus and cervix.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest pelvic organ prolapse, and the most common ligament involved is the uterosacral ligament. The infundibulopelvic ligament is involved in supporting the ovary, the cardinal ligament is involved in supporting the cervix and vagina, and the round ligament is involved in supporting the uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pelvic examination shows an irreducible pink globular mass protruding out of the vagina, which suggests a vaginal prolapse. The loss of integrity of the uterosacral ligament is most commonly involved in vaginal prolapse, therefore the correct answer is (B).
